snippet: As voters chose Saturday between an ex-finance minister and an opposition politician, the Taliban appeared not to have launched any major attacks, at least in urban areas.
abstract: Voter turnout in the second round of Afghanistan's presidential election is higher than expected, and despite Taliban threats, no major attacks appear to have been carried out; opposition politician Abdullah Abdullah won most votes in the first round over former finance minister Ashraf Ghani, although the second round is expected to be more competitive.

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Ahmad Shakib, Haris Kakar and Jawad Sukhanyar from Kabul, and Taimoor Shah from Kandahar, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: As voters chose Saturday between an ex-finance minister and an opposition politician, the Taliban appeared not to have launched any major attacks, at least in urban areas.

headline.main: Afghans, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal, Vote With Guarded Optimism
headline.print_headline: Afghans, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal, Vote With Guarded Optimism
